title: How to Make Basil Oil

methods.name: Making Blanched and Blended Basil Oil

steps.headline: Pick fresh basil leaves.
steps.description: You'll need several handfuls of basil leaves to make 1 1/2 cups of packed leaves. You can use basil fresh from your garden, from the supermarket, or from a local farmer's market. Basil comes in many varieties. The kind you can most easily find in the United States is sweet basil, which is perfect for use in Italian dishes and soups. Sweet Thai basil is often used in Asian cooking; it is slightly spicier with hints of licorice and cloves. Lemon basil has hints of lemon along with the typical sweet basil flavors. Purple basil types, such as dark opal basil or purple ruffles basil, are also spicier than sweet basil. You can use any of these basil types for your basil oil; it just depends on your taste preference and how you want to use the oil.

steps.headline: Bring a pot of water to boil.
steps.description: Using a medium pot, fill it with water. Bring it to a boil on the stove.

steps.headline: Add the 1 1/2 cups of basil to the water.
steps.description: You can leave them in there for as little as 10 seconds  or for up to 60 seconds. The longer you leave it in, the more limp your leaves will be, and you may lose some of the flavor if you leave it in for too long. Blanching the basil helps to maintain its color.

steps.headline: Place in a strainer.
steps.description: Dump the pot of water into a strainer, letting the water drain off. Run the leaves under cold water to stop the cooking process. Dump the leaves on a paper towel to dry.

steps.headline: Pat dry.
steps.description: Use paper towels to the basil dry from the top. Do not squeeze the basil because you will release too much of the flavor into the paper towels.

steps.headline: Add the basil and oil to a blender.
steps.description: Dump the leaves into a blender or food processor. Also add in the 3/4 cup of olive oil.

steps.headline: Blend the mixture.
steps.description: Set the blender or food processor to puree, and blend the mixture until the leaves are smoothly incorporated into the oil.

steps.headline: Keep in the refrigerator.
steps.description: If you don't use the basil oil immediately, keep it in the refrigerator in a covered container for 7 days.

methods.name: Creating Blended and Cooked Basil Oil

steps.headline: Choose a fresh bunch of basil.
steps.description: Look for bright, green leaves without brown spots. You can purchase your basil or pick it from your garden. Remove the leaves from the stems, discarding the stems. This method tends to bring out a stronger flavor in the oil, as the basil is cooked in the oil rather than in the water.

steps.headline: Add the basil and oil to a blender.
steps.description: In a blender or food processor, pour in 1 cup of oil, and add the bunch of basil leaves. Blend the mixture until you have made it smooth.

steps.headline: Heat a small skillet.
steps.description: Place a small skillet on the stove, and turn it to medium to medium-high heat.

steps.headline: Add the basil oil.
steps.description: Pour the basil oil into the skillet, and let it heat for about 3 minutes. Take the pan off the heat. Do not let the oil boil. It should stay at a light simmer, so turn down the heat if the oil is getting too hot.

steps.headline: Strain the oil.
steps.description: Place a fine mesh strainer over an airtight container with its lid off. Pour the oil through the strainer. Don't push on the pulp, as it can make it fall through the strainer. Gently shake or tap the strainer to help the oil through.

steps.headline: Keep the oil in the refrigerator.
steps.description: Place the oil in the refrigerator. It should be good for about a week.

steps.headline: Top toast with it.
steps.description: Cut up fresh French bread into slices. Toast it in the oven or on the grill, and then drizzle the basil olive oil over it.

steps.headline: Create stacked caprese salad.
steps.description: Layer tomato slices and fresh mozzarella slices together. Drizzle the oil over the top and a light sprinkling of salt for a simple caprese salad.

steps.headline: Make it a soup topping.
steps.description: Whether your eating tomato soup, gazpacho, or Italian wedding soup, basil oil makes a delicious topping for any Italian-themed soup. Just drizzle a little on top right before serving.

steps.headline: Try it on an open-faced sandwich.
steps.description: Make a traditional open-face breakfast sandwich with bacon and eggs. Pour a little oil over the top for added flavor. It also works well with other sandwiches, such as turkey and gouda.

steps.headline: Toss with vegetables.
steps.description: Steam your vegetables as usual. Pour in a little basil oil, and toss the vegetables until the oil coats them. Sprinkle salt over the top.
